sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I, faine, dissemble, Las we are now growne old, weake sighted, alas any one fooles vs.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I deepely vow my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Peace, bee not damnde, haue pitty on your soule,
I confesse sweet Prince for you to loue my daughter,
Young and wittie, of equall mixture both of minde and body,
Is neither wondrous nor vnnaturall,
Yet to forsweare and vow against ones heart,
Is full of base, ignoble cowardise,
Since ti's most plaine, such speeches, do contemne
Heauen, and feare men (that's sentious now)

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: My gratious Lord if I vnknowingly haue er'de,

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Vnknowingly, can you blush my Lord:
Vnknowingly, why can you write these lines?
Present this scarffe, vnknowingly my Lord,
To my deare daughter? vm, vnknowingly?
Can you vrge your suite, preferre your gentlest loue,
In your owne right, to her too easy breast:
That God knowes takes too much compassion on yee,
(And so shee praide me say) vnknowingly my Lord?
If you can act these thinges vnknowingly,
Know wee can know your actions so vnknowen,
For wee are old? I will not say in witte,
(For euen iust worth must not approue it selfe)
But take your skarfe, for she vowes sheele not weare it.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Nay but my Lord—

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Nay but my Lord, my Lord.
You must take it, weare it, keepe it,
For by the honour of our house and bloud;
I will deale wisely, and be prouident,
Your father shall not say I pandarizde,
Or fondly winkt at your affection,
No weele be wise, this night our daughter yeeldes
Your fathers answere, this night we inuite
Your presence therefore to a feastfull waking,
To morrow to Ferrara you returne,
With wished answere to your royall father,
Meane time as you respect our best relation
Of your faire bearing, (Granuffo ist not good?)
Of your faire bearing, rest more anxious,
(No anxious is not a good word) rest more vigilant
Ouer your passion, both forbeare and beare,
Anexou è ampexou, (that's Greeke to you now.)
Else your youth shall finde,
Our nose not stuft, but we can take the winde,
And smell you out, I say no more but thus,
And smell you out, what, ha not wee our eies,
Our nose and eares, what, are these haires vnwise?
Looke too't. Tibereo reads the imbroder 〈◊〉 skarfs. quos ego, a figure called Aposiopesis or Increpatio.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Proue you but iustlie, louing and conceiue me,
Iustice shall leaue the gods before I leaue thee:
Imagination proue as true, as thou art sweete
And tho the Duke seeme wise, heele finde this straine
When two harts yeelde consent, all thwartinges vaine.
O quick deuisefull strong braind Dulcimel
Thou art too full of witte to be a wife,
Why dost thou loue? or what strong heat gaue life
To such faint hopes? O woman thou art made
Most onelie of, and for deceit, thy forme
Is nothing but delusion of our eyes,
Our eares, our heartes, and sometimes of our hands,
Hipocrisie and vanitie brought forth,
Without male heat, thy most most monstrous being
Shall I abuse my royall fathers trust,
And make my selfe a scorne, the very foode
Of rumor infamous? shall I that euer loathede,
A thought of woman, now begin to loue,
My worthy fathers right, breake faith to him that got me
To get a faithlesse woman?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: True my worthy Lord, your grace is verè pius.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: To take from my good father the pleasure of his eyes,
And of his hands, imaginary solace of his fading life.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: His life that onely liues to your sole good,

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: And my selfe good, his lifes most onely end.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Which O may neuer end.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Yes Fawne in time, we must not prescribe to nature, euery thing: ther's some end in euery thing.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: But in a woman, yet as she is a wife, she is
Oftentimes the end of her husband

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Shal I, I say?—

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Shall you I say confound your owne faire hopes,
Crosse all your course of life, make your selfe vaine,
To your once steady grauenes, and all to second
The ambitious quicknes of a monstrous loue,
Thats onely out of difficultie borne,
And followed onelie for the miracle,
In the obtaining? I would ha ye now,
Tell her father all.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Vncompassionate vilde man, shall I not pittie, if I cannot loue?
Or rather shall I not for pittie loue,
So wondrous wit in so most wondrous beautie,
That with such rarest arte and cunning meanes
Entreates? what (I thing valules) am not,
Worthie but to graunt, my admiration,
Are fathers to be thought on in our loues?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: True right sir, fathers or friends, a crowne,
And loue hath none, but are allied to themselues alone,
Your father I may boldlie say, hee's an Asse,
To hope that youle forbeare to swallow,
What he cannot chew, nay e't is iniustice truelie,
For him to judge it fit, that you should starue.
For that which onelie hee can feast his eye withall,
And not disgest.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O Fawne what man of so colde earth
But must loue such a wit in such a body,
Thou last and onelie rarenes of heauens workes,
From best of man made modell of the Gods:
Diuinest woman, thou perfection
Of all proportions Beutie, made when, Ioue was blith,
Well filde with Nectar, and full friendes with man,
Thou deare as aire, necessarie as sleepe,
To carefull man: woman, O who can sin so deepely,
As to be curst from knowing of the pleasures,
Thy soft society, modest amorousnes,
Yeeldes to our tedious life. Fawne, the Duke shal not know this

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Vnlesse you tell him, but what hope can liue in you,
When your short stay, and your most shortned conference.
Not onely actions, but euen lookes abstrude,
Cut off all possibilities of obtaining.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Tush Fawne, to violence of womens loue and wit
Nothing but not obtayning is impossible,
Notumque furens quid foemina possit.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But then how rest you to your father true?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: To him that onely can giue dues, she rests most due. Exit

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Euen so? he that with safety would wel lurke in courts,
To best elected ends, of force is wrung,
To keepe broade eyes, soft feet, long ears, & most short tongue.
For ti's of knowing creatures the maine art,
To vse quicke hammes, wide armes and most close heart.

div.head: ACTVS QVARTVS

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why ti's a most wel in fashion affection Dona Garbetza your Knight S. Amaros is a man of a most vnfortunate back, spits white, has an ill breath, at three after dinner goes to the Bath, takes the diet, nay which is more, takes Tobacco, therefore with great authority you may cuckolde him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p:
I hope so, but would that friend my brother discouer
me, would he wrong himselfe, to preiudice me?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: No preiudice deare Garbetza, his brother your husband right, he cuckold his eldest brother, true, hee gets her with child, iust.

sp.speaker: Garb.
sp.p: Sure thers no wrong in, right, true, and iust.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And indeede since the vertue of procreation growed hopeles in your husband, to whome should you rather commit your loue and honour to, then him that is most like and neere your husband, his brother, but are you assured your friend and brother rests intirelie constant solely to you?

sp.speaker: Garb.
sp.p: To me? O Fawne, let me sigh it with ioy into thy bosome, my brother has been woed by this & that and tother Lady to entertaine than (for I ha seen their letters) but his vow to me O Faw, is most immutable, vnfaining, peculiar, & indeed deserued.

div.stage: Enter Puttotta and a Page, Puttotta with a letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Neuer intreat me, neuer beseech me, to haue pittie forsooth on your Master, M. Herod: Let him neuer be so daringly ambitious, as to hope with all his vowes and protestations to gaine my affection, gods my discretion? has my my sutlery, tapstry, laundrie, made mee be tane vpp at the Court, preferde mee to a husband, and haue I adaunc't my husband with the labour of mine owne bodie, from the blacke guarde, to bee one of the Dukes drūmers, to make him one of the court forkers? shal I that purefy many Lords & some Ladies can tel who weares perfumes who plaisters, and for why, know whose a gallant, of a chast shirt and who not; shall I become, or dares your master thinke I will become, or if I would becom, presumes your Master to hope I would become one of his common feminines? no let M. Herod bragge of his brothers wife, I skorne his letters, and her leauings at my heele, ifaith and so tell him.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Nay costlie, deare Puttotta, Mistres Puttotta, madam Puttotta O be mercifull to my languishing master, hee may in time growe great and wel grac't Courtier, for hee weares yellow already, mixe therefore your loues, as for madam Garbetza his brothers wife, you see what he writes there.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p:
I must confesse he saies shee is a spinie, greene creature, of an vnholesome barren bloud and cold imbrace, a bony thing of most vnequall hyppes, vneuen eyes, ill rankt teeth, and indeede one, but that shee hires him, he endures not, yet, for al this
does hee hope to dishonest me: I am for his betters, I would he should well know it, for more by many then my husband, know I am a woman of a knowne, sound and vpright carriage and so he shall finde if he deale with me, and so tel him I pray you, what does he hope to make me one of his gils, his puncks, pole cats, flirrs and feminines?

div.stage: Exit as Puttotta goes out she flinges away the letter, the page puts it vp, and as he is talking Hercules steales it out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Alas my miserable maister, what suds art thou washt into? thou art borne to be scornde of euery carted community, and yet heele out cracke a Germaine when hee is drunke, or a Spaniard after he hath eaten a Fumatho, that he haz lyen with that and that, and tother Lady, that hee lay last night in such a madonnas chamber, tother night he lay in such a Countesses couch, to night he lies in such a Ladies closet, when poore I know all this while he only lied in his throat.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Madam let me sigh it in your bosome, how immutable and vnfainting and indeede—

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Fawne I will vndo that raskall, he shall sterue for any further maintenance.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: You may make him come to the couering and recouering of his old dublets.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: He was in faire hope of prouing heire to his elder brother, but he has gotten me with child.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: So, you withdrawing your fauour, his present meanes faile him, and by getting you with child, his future meanes for euer rest despairefull to him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O heauen that I could curse him beneath damnation, impudent varlet: by my reputation Fawne, I onely lou'de him, because I thought I onely did not loue him, he vowed infinit beauties doted on him, alas I was a simple country Ladie, wore gold buttons, trunck sleeues, and flaggon bracelets, in this state of innocency was I brought vp to the Court.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And now in stead of country innocency, haue you got court honesty: well Madam leaue your brother to my placing, he shall haue a speciall cabin in the ship of fooles.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Right, remember hee got his elder brothers wife with child, and so depriude himselfe of th'inheritance.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: That will stow him vnder hatches I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: And so depriude himselfe of inheritance, deare Fawne be my champion.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The very scourge of your most basely offending brother

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Ignoble villaine, that I might but see thee wretched without pitty, and recouerie, wel. Enter Herod and Nymphadoro

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Stand Herod, you are full met sir.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: But not met, ful sir, I am as gaunt as a hunting gelding after 3. traind sents, fore Venus fanne I haue beene shaling of peascods, vpon foure great Madonnas haue I this after noone grafted the forked tree,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: Possible? fie on this satiety, tis a dul, blunt, weary, & drowsie passion; who would be a proper fellow to be thus greedily deuoured & swallowed among Ladies? faith tis my torment, my very rack.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Right Herod, true, for imagine all a man possest with a perpetuall pleasure, like that of generation, euen in the highest lushiousnes, he straight sinkes as vnable to beare so continuall, so pure, so vniuersall a sensuality.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: By euen truth ti's very right, & for my part woulde I were eunuch't rather then thus suckt away with kisses, infeebling daliance, & O the falling sicknes on them all, why did reasonable nature giue so strange, so rbellious, so tirannous, so insatiate parts of appetite to so weake a gouernes a woman.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Or why O custome didst thou oblige them to modesty, such cold temperance, that they must bee wooed by men, courted by men? why all know, they are more full of strong desires, those desires most impatient of delay, or hinderance, they haue more vnrulie passions then men, and weaker reason to temper those passions then men.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Why then hath not the discretion of nature thought it iust, that customary coines, old fashions, terms of honor & of modesty for sooth, all laide aside, they court not vs, beseech not vs, rather for sweetes of loue, then we them, why? by Ianus women are but men turnde the wrong side outward.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
O sir nature is a wise workeman, she knowes right well that if women should wooe vs to the art of loue, wee should all be vtterly shamd, how often shold they take vs vnprouided when
they are alwaies ready.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: I sir, right sir, to some few such vnfortunate handsome fellowes as my selfe am to my griefe I know it.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why here are two perfect creatures, the one Nymphadoro, loues all, and my Herod here enjoyes all.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Faith some score or two of Ladies or so, rauish mee among them, deuide my presents, and wold indeed ingrosse me were I indeed such an asse as to be made a Monopoly of: looke sirrah what a vilde hande one of them writes, who would euer take this for a. d. deerest, or reade this, for onely, onely deerest.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Heres a lye indeede.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: True, but heres another much more legible, a good secretary my most affected Herod, the vtmost ambition of my hopes and onely.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: There is one lye better shapte by ods.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Right, but heres a Ladies roman hand to mee is beyond all, looke yee, to her most elected seruant, and worthy friend, Herod Baldonzozo Esquier, I beleeue thou knowest what Countesses hand this is, Ile shew thee another.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: No good Herod, Ile show thee one now: To his most elected Mistresse and worthy laundresse, diuine mistresse Puttotta at her tent in the wood-yeard, or else where giue these.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Prethee ha silence whats that?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: If my teares or vowes, my faithfulst protestations on my knees.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Good hold.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Faire and onely loued laundresse.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Forbeare I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Might moue thy stony heart to take pitty on my sighs.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Do not shame me to the day of iudgement.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Alas I write it in passion, alas thou knowest besides my loathed sister thou art.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: For the Lords sake.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The onely hope of my pleasure, the onely pleasure of my hopes, be pleasde therefore to

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Cease I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
Pish, neere blush man, t'is an vncourtly quality, as for thy lying as long as theres policie int, it is very passable, wherfore haz heauen giuen man tong but to speake to a mans owne glory? hee that cannot swell bigger then his naturall skinne
nor seeme to bee in more grace then hee is, has not learn'd the very rudiments or A.B.C. of courtshippe.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Vpon my heart Fawne thou pleasest me to the soule, why looke you for mine owne part I must confesse.
See heeres the Dukes foole.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: A bord, a bord, a bord, al manner of fooles of Courteysie or country of what degree sex or nature.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: foole.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Herod.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: What, are yee ful fraughted, is your shippe wel foold?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O 'twas excellently thronged full, a Iustice of peace, tho he had beene one of the most illiterat asses in a Country could hardly ha got a hanging cabin. O we had first some long fortunate greate Politicians that were so sottishlie paradized as to thinke when popular hate seconded Princes displeasure to them, any vnmerited violence could seeme to the world iniustice, some purple fellowes whome chaunce reared, and their owne deficiences of spirit hurled downe, wee had some courtiers that ore bought their offices & yet durst fall in loue, Priests that for-sooke their functions to avoid a thawart stroake with a wet finger. But nowe alas Fawne, now thers space and place.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why/ how gat al these forth, was not the warrant strong?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but they got a supersedeas, al of them proued them selues eyther knaues or madd men, and so were all let go, thers none left nowe in our shippe, but a few Cittizens, that let their wiues keepe their shoppe books, some philosophers, and a few Critiques; one of which Critiques has lost his flesh with fishing at the measure of Plautus verses, another has vowde to get the consumption of the lungues, or to leue to posteritie the true orthography and pronunciation of laughing, a third hath melted a great deale a suet, worne out his thumbs with turning, read out his eyes and studied his face out of a sanguine into a meagre spawling fleamy lothsomenes, & al to finde but why mentula should be the feminine gender since the rule is Propria quae maribut tribuuntur mascilla dicas. These Philosophers, Critiques and all the maides we could find at 16. are all our fraught nowe.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: O then, your ship of fooles is full.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: True the maides at 17. fill it.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fill it quoth you alas we haue very fewe and these wee were faine to take vp in the country too.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But what Philosophers ha ye.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O very strange fellows one knowes nothing, dares not auer, he liues, goes, sees, feeles.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: A most insensible Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: An oher that there is no present time, and that one man to day, and to morrowe is not the same man, so that he that yesterday owed money to day owes none, because he is not the same man.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Would that Philosopher would hold good in law.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But why has the Duke thus labord to haue all the fools shipt out of his dominions.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marry because he would play the foole himselfe alone without any riuall.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Ware your breech foole.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I warrant thee old lad tis the priuiledge of poore fooles to talke before an intelligencer, mary if I could foole my selfe into a Lordship as I knowe some ha foole them selues out of a Lordeship were I grown some huge fellow & got the leer of the people vpon me if the fates had so decreed it, I should talke treason tho I neere opend my lips.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: In fatis agimur, cedite fatis, but how runnes rumor what breath's strongest in the Pallace, nowe I thinke you knowe all.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes wee fooles thinke wee knowe all the Prince hath audience to night, is feasted and after supper is intertainde with no comedie maske or barriers but with.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: What I prethe?

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: What I prethe?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: With a most new and speciall shape of delight.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: What for Ioues sake?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marie gallants, a session, a generall councell of loue summond in the name of Don Cupid to which vpon paine of their mistres displeasure shall appeare all fauour wearers, sonnet mongers, health drinkers, & neat in riches of barbers, & perfumers, & to conclude al that can wyhee or wag the taile, are vpon grieuous paines of their backe sūmond to be assistant in that Session of loue.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
Hold, hold, do not paule the delight before it come to
our pallat, & what other rumor keeps aire on mens lungs.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Other egregiousnes of folly ha you not heard of Don. Zucone.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: What of him good foole.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hee is separated.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Diuorcd.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: That salt that criticisme, that very all epigram of a woman, that Analysis, that compendium of witnes.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Now Iesu what wordes the foole has.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: We ha stil such words but I wil not vnshake the iest before it be ripe and therefore kissing your worships fingers in most sweet tearmes without any sense and with most fair looks without any good meaning I most courtlike take my leaue ba suus manus devostro Signioria.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Stay foole weele follow thee, for fore heauen we must prepare our selues for this session.

div.stage: Enter Zuccone pursued by Zoya on her knees attended by Ladies

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I wil haue no mercy, I will not relent, iustice beard is shauen, and it shal giue thee no hold, I am separated and I wil be seperated.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Deare my Lord husband.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Hence creature, I am none of thy husband or father of thy bastard, no I wilbe tyranous and a most deepe reuenger the order shall stand ha, thou Queane I ha no wife now.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Hence auant I will marie a woman with no wombe, a creature with two noses, a wench with no haire rather then remarie thee, nay I wil first marrie, mark me I wil first marry, obserue me, I wil rather marie a woman that with thirst drinkes the blood of man: nay, heed me a woman that wil thrust in crouds, a lady that being with child ventures the hope of her wombe, nay giues two crownes for a roume to behold a goodlie man three partes a liue quartered, his priuities hacked off, his belly launcht vp. Nay Ile rather marrie a woman to whom this smoking, hideous, bloudful, horred, tho most iust spectacles, are very lust, rather, then reaccept thee, was I not a handsome fellow from my foote to my feather, had I not wit, nay, which is more, was I not a Don. and didst thou Acteon me, did I not make thee a Lady.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And did she not make you a more worshipfull thing, a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I married thee in hope of children.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And has not she shewed herselfe fruitfull that was got with child without helpe of her husband?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Ha thou vngratful, immodest, vnwise, & one that gods my witnes I ha lou'd, but goe thy waies twist with whom thou wilt, for my part tha'st spun a faire thread, whole kisse the now whole court the now, whole ha the now?

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: Pittie the frailtie of my sexe sweete Lord.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: No, pittie is a foole, and I wil not weare hir coxcombe, I haue vowde to loth thee, the Irish man shall hate aquauity, the welsh man cheese, the dutch man shall loth salt butter before I reloue thee, do's the babe pule? thou should'st ha cride beefore, t'is to late nowe, no, the trees in autumne shal sooner call backe the spring with sheding of their leeues; then thou reuerse my iust irreuocable hatred with thy teares, away goe vaunt.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Nay but most of this is your fault that for many yeres onely vpon meere mistrust seuer'd your body from your Lady and in that time gaue opportunity turn'de a iealous asse hired and some to trie and tempt your Ladies honour whilest she with all posible industrie of apparant merit diuerting your vnfortunate suspition.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I know't I confesse, all this I did and I doe glorie in't, why? cannot a young Lady for many monthes keepe honest? no, I misthought it, my wife had wit, beautie, health, good birth, faire clothes and a passing bodie, a Ladie of rare discourse, quicke eye, sweete language, alluring behauiour, and exquisit entertainement. I misthought it, I feard, I doubted, and at the last I found it out, I prayse my witte I knewe I was a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An excellent wit.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: True Fawne, you shall read of some Lords that haue had such a wit I can tell you, & I found it out, that I was a Cuckold

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Which now you haue found you will not be such an asse as Cesar, great Pompey, Lucullus, Anthony, or Cato & diuerse other Romans, cuckolds, who all knewe it, & yet were nere diuorc'd vpon't, or like that smith-God Vulcan who hauing taken his wifetaking, yet was presently appeased, and entreated to make an Armour for a bastard of hers Eneas.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
No the Romans were asses. & thought that a woman might mixe her thigh with a strnager wantonly, & yet stil loue her husband
band matrimonially.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: As indeede they say many maried men, lye sometime with strange women, whom, but for the instant vse, they abhor.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: And as for Vulcan t'was humanitye more then humane; such excesse of goodnesse for my part only belong to the Gods.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Asse for you.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: As for me my Fawne I am a batcheller now.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: But you are a Cuckold still, and one that knowes himselfe to be a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Right, thats it and I knew it not, t'were nothing and if I had not pursude it too, it had lyen in obliuion, and shaddowed in doubt, but now I ha blaz'de it.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The world shall knowe what you are.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: True, ile pockit vp no hornes, but my reuenge shall speake in thunder.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Indeede I must confesse I know twenty are Cuckoldes honestly & decently enough a worthy gallant spirit (whose vertue suppresseth his mishap) is lamented but not disesteem'd by it: Yet the world shall know—

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I am none of those silen Coxcombs, it shall out.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And although it be no great part of iniustice, for him to be struck with the scabbard that haz struck with the blade (for there is few of vs but hath made some one cuckold or other)

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: True I ha don't my selfe.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Yet.—

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yet I hope a man of wit may preuent his owne mishap or if he can preuent it.—

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Yet—

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yet make it knowne yet, and so knowne that the world may tremble with onely thinking of it. Well Fawne whome shall I marie now? O heauen! that God made for a man no other meanes of procreation and maintaining the world peopled but by women, O that we could encrease like roses by being slipt one from another or like flies procreat with blowing, or any other way then by a woman, by women who haue no reason in their loue, or mercy in their hate, no rule in their pitty, no pitty in their reuenge, no judgement to speak, & yet no patience to hold their tongues; mans opposit, the more held doun; they swel, aboue them naught but will, beneath them naught but hel

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Or that since heauen hath giuen vs no other meanes to allay our furious appetite, no other way of increasing our progenie, since we must intreat and beg for asswagement of our passions, and entertainment of our affections, why did not heauen make vs a nobler creature then women to shew vnto, some admirable, deitie of an vncorruptible beauty that be worth our knees, the expence of our heat, and the crinkling of our.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: But that we must court, sonnet, flatter, bribe, kneele, sue to so feeble and imperfect, in constant, idle, vaine, hollow, bubble, as woman is. O my face.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: O my Lord looke who here comes.

div.stage: Enter Zoya supported by a gentleman vssher followed by Herod and Nymphadora with much state, soft musik playing.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Death a man, is she deliuered?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Deliuerd, yes. O my Don. deliuered, yes Dona Zoya the grace of society, the musik of sweetly agreeing perfection, more clearely chast then ice or frozen raine, that glory of her sexe, that wonder of witte, that beauty more freshy then any coole and trembling wind, that now only wish of a man is deliuered, is deliuered.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: how

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: From Don. Zuc. that dry skalines, that sarpego, that barren drouth and shame of all humanity.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: What fellowes that.

sp.speaker: Nym. Don. Zuc.
sp.p: your sometime husband.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: alas poore creature.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The Princes prayes your company. All but Hercules,

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: I waite vpon her pleasure. Zuccone. Herod, and Nim. depart.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Gentlemen why hazard you your reputation in shamefull company with such a branded creature,

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: Miserable man whose fortune were beyond teares to be pittied, but that thou art the ridiculous author of thine owne laught at mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Without paraphrase your meaning.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Why thou womans foole?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Good gentlemen let one die but once.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Was not thou most curstfully madd to seuer thy selfe from such an vnequalde rarity.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Is shee not a strumpet? Is shee not with Childe?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: yes with feathers.

sp.speaker: Herc
sp.p: why weakenes of reason, couldst not perceiue all was faind to be rid of thee?

sp.speaker: Zuc
sp.p: Of me.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: she with child, vntrodden snow is not so spotles

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: Chast as the first voice of a new borne infant,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: knowe shee grewe lothing of thy ielousie,

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.l: thy most pernicious curiosity,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: whose suspitions made her vnimitable graces motiue of thy base ielousy.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: why beast of man?

sp.speaker: Nym,
sp.p: wretched aboue expression that snoredst ouer a beautie which thousands desired, neglecst her bed, for whose enioying a very saint would haue sued.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: defam'd her.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: suggested priuily against her.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: gaue foule language publickly of her.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: and now lastly don that for her which she onely praide for, and wisht as wholesome aire for, namely to be from such an vnworthy.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: senseles.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: inuirious.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: malitious.

sp.speaker: Herod
sp.p: suspitious.

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.p: mishaped.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: ill languidg'd.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.l: vnworthy

sp.speaker: Nym
sp.p: ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: iealous.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: arch cox-combe as thou art. Exeunt Nym. & Herod.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O I am sicke, my bloud ha's the crampe, my stomacke or'eturnes; O I am very sicke.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: why my sweete Don. you are no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: thats the griefe on't

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: that's, the griefe ont that I ha wrongd so sweete (and now in my knowledg) so delicate a creature, O me thinkes I embrace her yet.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: alas my Lord you haue done her no wrong, no wrong in the world, you haue done her a pleasure, a great pleasure, a thousand gentlemen, nay dukes will be proude to accept your leauings, your leauings, now is she courted, this heire sendes her iewels, that lord proffers her ioynters, tother knight proclaimes challenges, to maintain her, the only not beautifull, but very beautie of woemen.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: but I shall neuer embrace her more.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: nay that's true, that's most true (I would not afflict you, onely thinke how vnrelentles you were to her but supposed fault.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O tis true, too true.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: think how you scornd her teares,

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: most right,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Teares that were only shed I woulde not vex you in very griefe to see you couet your owne shame.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Too true, too true.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: For indeede she is the sweetest modest soule, the fullest of pittie.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O yes, O yes.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The softnesse and very courrtesie of her sexe as one that neuer lou'd any—

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: But mee.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: So much that he might hope to dishonour her, nor anie so little that he might feare she disdaind him. O the graces made her a soule as soft as spotles down vpon the swans faire brest, that drue bright Cythereas chariot, yet thinke (I woulde not vexe you) yet thinke how cruell you were to her.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: As a Tiger, as a very Tiger.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: And neuer hope to be reconcild, neuer dreame to bee reconcild, neuer

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Neuer, alas good Fawne what woldst wish me to do now?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Faith go hang your selfe my Don. thats best sure.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Nay thats too good, for Ile do worse then that, Ile marie againe; where canst pick out a morsell for me Fawne?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: There is a modest matron like creature—

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: What yeeres Fawne.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Some fower score wanting one.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: A good sober age, is she wealthy?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Very wealthy.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Shee has three haires on her scalpe and fower teeth in her head, a browe wrinckled and puckred like old parchment halfe burnt, she haz had eies, no womans jaw-bones are more apparant, her sometimes enuious lips, now shrink in, and giue her nose and her chin leaue to kisse each other verie moistlye; as for her reuerend mouth it seldome opens, but the very breath that flies out of it, infects the fowls of the aire, and makes them drop down dead, her brests hang like cobwebs, her flesh will neuer make you cuckold, her bones may.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: But is she welthy

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Very wealthie,

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: And will she ha mee art sure?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: No sure, she will not haue you, why do you thinke that a waiting woman of three bastards, a strumpet nine times carted or a hag whose eies shoot poison, that has beene an ould witch, and is now turning into a gib-cat wil ha you? mary Don. Zucone the contempt of women, and the shame of men, that has afflicted, contemnd, so choise a perfection as Dona Zoyas.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Alas Fawne I confesse, what wouldst ha me do?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
Hang your selfe you shal not, marrie you cannot, ile tell yee what you shal do, there is a ship of fooles setting foorth, if you make good meanes & intreat hard, you may obtaine a passageman,
be maisters mate I warrant yow.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Fawne, thou art a scuruie bitter knaue, and dost flout Dons to their faces, twas thou flatteredst me to this, and now thou laugh'st at me, dost? though indeede I had a certaine procliuity, but thou madest me resolute, dost grinne and gearne? O yow comforters of life, helpes in sicknesse, ioyes in death, & preseruers of vs, in our children, after death, women, haue mercie on me.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: O my Don, that God made no other meanes of procreation but by these women, I speake it not to vexe you.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: O Fawne, thou hast no mercy in thee, dost thou leere on me? wel, ile creepe vpon my knees to my wife, dost laugh at me? dost gearne at me? dost smile? dost leere on me, dost thou? O I am an Asse, true, I am a Coxcombe, wel, I am mad, good: A mischeife on your cogging tongue, your soothing throat, your oylie iawes, your supple hammes, your dissembling smiles, and O the graund Diuill on you all: when mischiefe fauours our fortunes, and we are miserably, tho iustly wretched
sp.l: More pittie, comfort, and more helpe we haue
In foes profest, then in a flattering knaue. Exit

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Thus few strike saile vntill they run on shelfe,
The eye sees all thinges but his proper selfe,
In all thinges curiosity hath beene
Vitious at least, but herein most pernitious,
What madnes ist to search and find a wound,
For which there is no cure? and which vnfound
Neere rankles, whose finding onely woundes
But he that vpon vaine surmise forsakes
His bed thus long, onely to search his shame,
Giues to his wife youth, opportunity,
Keepes her in idlefull delitiousnesse,
Heates and inflames imagination,
Prouokes her to reuenge with churlish wronges,
What should he hope but this? why should it lie in women,
Or euen in chastity it selfe (since chastiti's a female)
T'auoide desires so ripened, such swetes so canded;
But she that hath out-borne such masse of wronges,
Out-dur'de all persecutions, all contempts,
Suspects, disgrace, all wantes, and all the mischeifs
The basenes of a cankerd churle could cast vpon her,
With constant vertue, best fainde chastitie,
And in the end turnes all his iealousies,
To his owne skorne, that Lady I emplore,
It may be lawfull not to praise, but euen adore.

div.stage: Enter Gonzago, Granuffo, with full state. Enter the Cornets sounding.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Are our sportes readie, is the Prince at hand?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: The Prince is now arriude at the Court gate.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What meanes our daughters breathles hast?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O my princely father now or neuer let your princely wisedome appeare.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Feare not our daughter, if it rest within humaine reason I warrant thee, no I warrant thee, Granuffo if it rest in mans capacity, speake deare daughter.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: My Lord the Prince.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: The Prince, what of him deare daughter?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O Lord what wisedome our good parents neede, to shield their chickens from deceipts, & wiles of kite like youth.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Her very phrase displayes whose childe she is.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Alas had not your grace beene prouident, a very Nestor in aduise and knowledge, ha, where had you poore Dulcimel beene now, what vaines had not I beene drawne into?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Fore God, shee speakes very passionately. Alas daughter, heauen giues euery man his talent, indeed vertue & wisedom are not fortunes giftes, therefore those that fortune cannot make vertuous, shee commonly makes rich, for our owne part wee acknowledge heauens goodnes, and if it were possible, to bee as wise againe as wee are, wee would neare impute it to our selues: for as wee bee flesh and bloud, alas we are fooles, but as wee are Princes, Schollars, and haue reade Cicero de Oratore, I must confesse there is another matter int, what of the Prince deere daughter?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Father doe you see that tree, that leanes iust on my chamber window?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What of that tree? Enter Tiberio with his traine.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O sir, but note the policie of youth, marke but the stratagems of working loue, The prince salutes me, and thus greetes my eare.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Speake softly, he is entred.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Although he knew, I yet stood wauering, what to elect, because though I affected, yet destitute of meanes to inioy each other, impossibilitie of hauing, might kill our hope and with our hope desires to inioy. Therefore to auoid all faint excuses, and vaine feares, thus he deuised: to Dulcimels chamber window. A well growne plain tree spreads his happie armes, by that in depth of night one may ascend, (dispight all fathers iealousies and feares) into her bed.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Speake low, the Prince both markes and listens.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: You shall prouide a Priest (quoth hee) in truth I promist & so you well may tell him, for I temporized and onelie held him off.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Politikely, our daughter to a haire.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: With full intention to disclose it all, to your preuenting wisedome.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I let me alone for that: but when intends he this inuasion? when will this Squirrile clime?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: O Sir in that is al, when but this night?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: This night?

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: This very night when the court reuels had o're wakt your spirites, and made them full of sleepe, then—

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Then, verbum sat sapienti: goe take your chamber, downe vpon your knees, thank god your father is no foolish sotte but one that can foresee and see. Exit Dulcimel .my Lord wee discharge your presence from our Court.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: What means the Duke?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: And if to morrow past you rest in Vrbin, the priuiledge of an ambassadour is taken from you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Good your grace some reason?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What, twise admonisht twise again offending?
And now growne blushles; you promis'd to gette into
Her chamber, she to get a priest,
Indeed she wisht me tell you she confest it,
And there despight all fathers Iealous feares,
To consumate full ioyes: know Sir our daughter
Is our Daughter, and has wit at will
To gull a thousand easie things like you:
But sir depart, the parliament prepar'd
Shall on without you, all the Court this night
Shall triumph, that our daughter has escapt,
Her honors blowing vppe; your end you see,
We speake but short but full, Socratice. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: What should I thinke, what hope, what but imagine of thes Enigmas?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Sure sir the Lady loues you
With violent passion, and this night prepares
A Priest with nuptiall rightes to entertaine you
In her most priuate chamber.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: This I know,
With too much torture, since meanes are all vnknowne,
To come vnto these endes, wheres this her chamber?
Then what meanes shall without suspition
Conuey me to her chamber? O these doubtes,
End in despaire— Enter Gonzago hastily.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Sir sir this plaine tree was not planted here
To get into my daughters chamber: and so she praide me tell you
What though the maine armes spreade into her window?
And easie labour climes it: Sir know
She has a voice to speake, and bid you welcome,
With so full breast that both your eares shall heare ant,
And so she praide me tell you: ha wee no braine;
Youth thinkes that age, Age knowes that youth is vaine. Exit

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why now I haue it Fawne, the way, the meanes, & meaning, good Duke, and t'were not for pitty, I could laugh at thee, Dulcimel I am thine most miraculously, I will now beginne to sigh, reade Poets, looke pale, go neately, and be most apparantly in loue, as for—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: As for you old father.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Alas he and all know, this an old saw hath bin,
Faiths-breach for loue, and kingdoms is no sin. Exit.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Where are we now, Cyllenian Mercurie?
And thou quicke issue of Ioues broken pate
Aide and direct vs: you better stars to knowledge
Sweete constellations that affect pure oyle,
And holy vigill of the pale cheeckt Muses,
Giue your best influence, that with able spright,
We may correct and please, giuing full light,
To euery angle of this various sense,
Works of strong birth, end better then commence. Exit.

div.head: ACTVS QVINTVS.
div.stage: Whilest the Act is a playing, Hercules and Tiberio enters, Tiberio climes the tree, and is receiued aboue by Dulcimel, Philocalia and a Preist: Hercules staies beneath.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Thou mother of chast dew, nightes modest lampe,
Thou by whose saint shine, the blushing louers,
Ioyne glowing cheekes, and mixe their trembling lips.
In vowes well kiste, rise all as full of splendor,
As my breast is of ioy- You Genitall,
You fruitefull well mixt heates: O blesse the sheetes,
Of yonder chamber, that Ferraraes Dukedome,
The race of princely issue be not cursde,
And ended in abhorred barrennes.
At length kill all my feares, nor let it rest,
Once more my tremblinges, that my too cold sonne,
(That euer scorner of humainer loues)
Will still contemne the sweetes of marriadge,
Still kill our hope of name in his dull coldnes,
Let it bee lawfull to make vse ye powers,
Of humaine weakenes, that pursueth still,
What is inhibited, and most affects,
What is most difficult to be obtainde:
So wee may learne, that nicer loue's a shade,
It followes fled, pursude, flies as afraide,
And in the end close all the various errors
Of passages, most truely comicall:
In morall learning with like confidence,
Of him that vowde good fortune of the sceane,
Shall neither make him fat, or bad make leane.

sp.speaker: Dondol.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why dost laugh foole, heeres no body with thee.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why, therefore doe I laugh, because theres no body with me, would I were a foole alone I faith, I am come to attend let me goe, I am sent to the Princes, to come & attend her father to the end of Cupids Parliament.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why, ha they sat already vpon any statutes?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sat I, all's agreede in the nether house:

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why, are they diuided?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O Im Cupids Parliament, all the young gallantes are a the nether house, and all the olde signiors that can but onely kisse are of the vpper house: is the Princes aboue?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Noe sure, I thinke the Princes is beneath, man, ha they supt foole?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O yes, the confusion of tongues, at the large Table is broke vppe, for see the presence filles; A foole, a foole, a foole my Coxcombe for a foole.

div.stage: Enter Sir Amaros, Herod Nymphadon, Garbetza, Donella and Poueia.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Stoppe Asse, whats matter idiot?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: O gallants, my fooles that were appointed to waight on Don Cupid. haue launcht out their ship to purge their stomackes on the water, and before Iupiter I feare, they will proue defectiue in their attendance.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Pish, foole, theyle float in with the next tide.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I, but whens, that? lets see mine Almanacke or prognostication.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: What, is this for this yeare?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: In true wisedome sir it is, Let mee see the moone, fore pitty, tis in the wayne, what griefe is this? that so great a planet should euer decline or loose splendore— ful sea at-

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: Wheres the signe now foole?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: In Capricorne, Sir Amoroso.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: What strange thing dos this Almanack speak of foole?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Is this your lady Sir Amarous?

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: It is, kisse her foole.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: You may kisse her now, she is maried.

sp.speaker: S: Am.
sp.l: So he might ha done before,

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: In sober modesty Sir, I doe not vse to doe it behind.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Good foole be acquainted with this lady to, shee's of a very honest nature I assure thee.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I easily beleeue you sir, for she hath a very vile face, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: But what strange thinges dos thy Almanacke speake of good foole?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: That this yeare no childe shal be begotten, but shall haue a true Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.p: Thats good newes ifaith, I am glad I got my wife with child this yeare,

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Why Sir Amaros this may be, and yet you not the true father, may it not Herod?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: But what more sayes it good Fawne?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Faith Lady very strange thinges, it sayes, that some Ladies of your hayre, shall haue feeble hams, short memories and very weake eye sight, so that they shall mistake their owne Page, or euen brother in law, sometimes for their husbandes.

sp.speaker: S. Am.
sp.p: Is that all Fawne?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No sir Amaros, heeres likewise prophesied a great skarsitie of Gentrie to ensue, and that some Bores shall be dubbed Sir Amoroso. A great scarsitie of Lawyers is likewise this yeare to ensue, so that some one of them shall be entreated to take fees a both sides.

div.stage: Enter Don Zuccone following Dona Zoia on his knees.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Most deere, deere Lady, wife, Lady, wife, O do not but looke on me, and ha some mercy.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: I will ha no mercie, I wil not relent.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Sweete Ladie.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: The order shall stand, I am separated, and I wil be separated.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Deere, my loue, wife.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Hence fellow, I am none of thy wife, noe I will be tyrannous and a most deepe reuenger, the order shal stand, I will marry a fellow that keepes a fox in his bosom, a goat vnder his arme holes, and a polecat in his mouth, rather then re-accept thee.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Alas, by the Lord Ladie what should I say? as heauen shall blesse me— what should I say?

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Kneele and crie man.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Was I not handsom, generous, honest enough from my foote to my feather, for such a fellow as thou art?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Alas I confesse I confesse.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: But goe thy waies & wiue with whome thou wilt for my part, thou hast spun a fair thread, whole kisse thee now? whole court thee now? whole ha thee now?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yet be a woman— and for Gods sake helpe mee.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: And doe not stand too stifly.

sp.speaker: Zucc.
sp.p: And doe not stand too stifly, doe you make an Asse of me? but let these raskals laugh at me, Alas what could I doe withall? t'was my destiny that I should abuse you.

sp.speaker: Zoya
sp.p: So it is your destiny that I should thus reuenge your abuse: No the Irishman shall hate Aquauitae, the Welshman cheese and the Dutchman salt butter before ile loue or receiue thee, dos he crie? dos the babe pule? t'is to late now, thou shouldest ha cried before, t'is to late now, goe bury thy head in silence, and let obliuion be thy vtmost hope.

div.stage: The Courtiers addresse themselues to dauncing, whilest the Duke enters with Granuffo, and takes his state.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Gallants to dancing, loud musicke, the dukes vpon entrance

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Are the sportes ready?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Ready.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Tis enough, of whose inuention is this Parliament?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Ours.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: T'is enough, this night we will exult, O let this night
Be euer memorizd with prouder triumphes,
Let it be writ in lasting Character,
That this night our great wisdome did discouer
So close a practise, that this night I say,
Our policy found out, nay dasht the driftes
Of the young Prince, and put him to his shiftes,
Nay past his shiftes, (fore Ioue we could make a good Poet)
Delight vs, on, we dain our princely care
We are well plesd to grace you, then skorne feare.
sp.stage: Cornets playing. Drunkennes, Sloth, Pride, & Plenty leads Cupid to his state, who is followed by Folly, warre, Beggary and Laughter.
sp.l: Stand t'is wisedome to acknowledge ignorance,
Of what we know not, we would not now proue foolish.
Expound the meaning of your shew.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Triumphant Cupid that sleepes on the soft cheeke
Of rarest beauty, whose thron's in Ladies eyes,
Whose force writh'd lightning from Ioues shaking hand,
Forc'd strong Alcides to resigne his club.
Pluckt Neptunes trident from his mighty arme,
Vnhelmed Mars, he (with those trophes borne,
Led in by Sloth, Pride, Plenty, Drunkennes.
Followde by Folly, Warre, Laughter, Beggary,
Takes his faire throne, sit pleasde for now we moue,
And speake not for our glorie, but for loue.

div.stage: Hercules takes a bowle of wine.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: A prety figure, what, begins this session with ceremony?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: With a full health to our great Mistresse Venus,
Let euery state of Cupids parliament, Hercule drinkes to health.
Begin the session, quod bonum faustumque sit precor.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Giu't vs, weele pledge, nor shall a man that liues,
In charity refuse it, I will not be so old,
As not be grac't to honour Cupid, giu't vs full,
When we were young, we could ha trold it off.
Drunke down a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: T'is lamentable, pitty your grace has forgot it: Drunkennes, O t'is a most fluent and swelling vertue, sure the most iust of all vertues, t'is iustice it selfe, for if it chance to oppresse and take too much, it presently restores it againe. It makes the king and the peasant equall, for if they are both drunke alike, they are both beastes alike: As for that most precious light of heauen Truth, if time bee the father of her, I am sure drunkennes is oftentimes the mother of her, and bringes her forth, Drunkennes bringes all out, for it bringes all the drinke out of the pot, all the witte out of the pate, and all the money out of the purse.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: My Lord Granuffo, this Fawne is an excellent fellow.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I warrant you for my Lord here.

sp.speaker: Cupid
sp.p: Since multitude of lawes are signes either of much tirannie in the prince, or much rebellious disobedience in the subiect, we rather thinke it fit to study, how to haue our old lawes thorowly executed, then to haue new statutes comborously inuented.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Afore Ioue he speakes very well.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: O sir, one is very eloquent, makes all men good Orators, himselfe then must needes be eloquent.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p:
Let it therefore be the maine of our assembly, to suruay our old lawes, and punish their transgressions, for that continually the complaints of louers ascend vp to our deity, that loue is abusde, and basely bought and solde, beautie corrupted,
affection fainde, and pleasure her selfe sophisticated. That young Gallants are proud in appetite, and weake in performance, that young Ladies are phantastically inconstant, old Ladies impudently vnsatiate: wiues complaine of vnmarried women, that they steale the dewes belonging to their sheetes: and maides exclaime vppon wiues, that they vniustly ingrosse all into their owne handes, as not content with their owne husbandes, but also purloyning that which shoulde bee their comfort: Let vs therefore be seuere in our iustice: And if any of what degree soeuer haue approuedly offended, let him be instantly vnpartially arrested and punished, reade our statutes.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: A statute made in the fiue thousand, fowre hundred, threescore and three yeare of the easefull raigne of the mighty potent Don Cupid Emperour of sighes, and protestations, great king of kisses: Archduke of dalliance, and sole lou'de of him, for the maintaining and releeuing of his olde souldiers, maimed or dismembred in loue.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Those that are lightlie hurt, shame to complaine; those that are deepely strucke, are past recouerie.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.p: On to the next.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An Act against the plurality of Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Reade.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
Whereas some ouer amorous and vnconscionable couetous young gallants without all grace of Venus, or the feare of Cupid in their mindes, haue at one time ingrossed the care or cures of diuers mistresses, with the charge of Ladies, into their owne tenure or occupation, whereby their mistresses must of necessitie bee very ill and vnsufficiently serued, and likewise many able portly Gallants, liue vnfurnished of competent entertainment to the merit of their bodies: and wheras likewise some other greedy strangers haue taken in the purlues, outset land, and the auncient commons of our soueraine Liege Don Cupid, taking in his very high waies, and inclosing them, and annexing them to their owne Lordships, to the much empouerishing and putting of diuers of Cupids true harts and loiall subiectes, to base and abhominable shifts: Bee it therefore enacted by the soueraigne authority and erected ensigne of Don Cupid, with the assent of some of the Lordes, most of the
Ladies, and all the Commons, that what person or persons soeuer, shall in the trade of honor, presume to weare at one time two Ladies fauors, or at one time shall earnestly court two women in the way of marriage, or if any vnder the degree of a Duke, shall keepe aboue twentie women of pleasure, a Dukes brother fifteene, a Lord ten, a knight or a Pentioner, or both fower, a gentleman two. shall ipso facto, bee arrested by follies mace, and instantly committed to the ship of fooles, without either baile or maine-prize, Millessimo centesimo, quingintesimo, quadragesimo nono. Cupidinis semper vnius. Nymphadoro to the barre.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Shame a folly, wil Fawne now turn an informer? dos he laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Domina Garbetza, did hee not euer protest, you were his most onely elected Mistres.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Domina Donella, did hee not euer protest you were his most onely elected Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Domina Poueia, did hee not euer protest, that you were his most onely elected Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Mercy.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Our mercy is nothing, vnlesse some Lady will beg thee.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Out vpon him, dissembling perfidious lyer.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Indeed tis no reason Ladies should beg liers.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Thus he that loueth many if once knowne, is iustly plagued to be belou'de of none. Exit.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
An act against counterfeiting of Cupids royall coine, & abusing his subiectes with false money. To the barre Sir Amaros. In most lamentable forme complaineth to your blinde celsitude, your distressed Orators, the women of the world, that in respect that many spendthriftes, who hauing exhausted and wasted their substance, and in stranger partes haue with emptie showes, treasonably purchased Ladies affections, without being of ability to pay them for it with currant money, and therefore haue deceitfully sought to satisfie them with counterfeite mettell, to the great displeasure, and no smal losse of your humblest subiectes. May it therefore with your pittifull assent been acted, that what Lord, Knight, or gentleman soeuer, knowing himselfe insufficient, bankerout, exhausted and wasted, shal trayterously dare to entertaine any lady, as wife, or mistresse, ipso facto to be seuered from all commercement
with women, his wife or mistresse in that state offending, to be forgiuen with a pardon of course, and himselfe instantly to be pressed to saile in the ship of fooles, without either baile or main-prise.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Sir Amarous is arrested.

sp.speaker: Sir Amar.
sp.p: Iudgement of the court.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I take my oath vpon thy brothers body, tis none of thine.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: By the hart of dissemblance, this Fawne has wrought with vs as strange Taylors work in corporate cities, where they are not free all inward, inward, he lurkt in the bosome of vs, & yet wee know not his profession: Sir let me haue counsell?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: T'is in great Cupids case, you may haue no counsell.

sp.speaker: Sir Amor.
sp.p: death a iustice, are we in Normandy, what is my Ladies doome then?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Acquited by the expresse parol of the statute, hence and in thy ignorance be quietly happie, away with him. on.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: An Act against forgers of loue letters, false braggarts of ladies fauours, and vaine boasters of counterfeit tokens.

sp.speaker: Herod.
sp.p: Tis I, tis I, I confesse guiltie, guilty.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: I will bee most humaine and right courteously languaged in thy correction, and onely say, thy vice from apparant here, has made thee an apparant beggar, and now of a false knaue, hath made thee a true foole: Folly to the shippe with him, and twice a day let him be duckt at the mayne-yeard.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Proceede.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An Act against slanderers of Cupids liege ladies names, and lewde defamers of their honors.

sp.speaker: Zucc.
sp.p: Tis I, tis I, I weepe and crie out, I haue been a most contumelious offender, my onely crie is miserere.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: If your relenting Lady wil haue pittie on you, the fault against our Deity be pardoned.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Madam if euer I haue found fauour in your eyes, if euer you haue thought me a reasonable handsome fellow, as I am sure before I had a beard, you might. O be mercifull!

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Well, vpon your apparant repentance, that all modest spectators may witnes, I haue for a short time onely thus faynedly hated you, that you might euer after truely loue me, vppon these cautions I reaccept you: first you shall vow.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I doe vow, as heauen blesse me, I will doe.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: What ere it be, say on I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: You shall vow.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: That you shall neuer.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Faine loue to my waiting woman or chamber maide.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: No

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Neuer promise them such a farme to their mariadge.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: If sheele discouer but whom I affect.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Or if they know none that theil but take a false oath; I do, onely to be ridde of mee.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I sweare I wil not, I will not onelie not counterfetlie loue your women, but I will truelie hate them an't be possible, so far from maintaining them that I will begger them, I wil neuer picke their trunkes for letters, search their pockets, ruffle their bosoms, or tear their foule smocks, neuer, neuer.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: That if I chance to haue a humor to be in a maske, you shall not grow Iealous.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: Or grudge at the expence.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Neuer, I wil eate mine own armes first.

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: That you shall not search, if my chamber dore hinges be oyld to auoid creaking.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: As I am a sensible creature—

sp.speaker: Zoy.
sp.p: Nor euer suspect the reason why my bedde-chamber floore is double matted.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: Not as I haue bloud in mee.

sp.speaker: Zoya.
sp.p: You shall vowe to weare cleane linnen, and feede wholsomelie.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.p: I and highly, I will take no more Tobacco, or come to your sheetes drunke, or get wenches, I wil euer feed on fried frogs, broild snayles, and boilde Lamstones, I will adore thee more then a mortall, obserue and serue you as more then a Mistresse, doe all duties of a husband, all offices of a man, all seruices of thy creature, and euer liue in thy pleasure, or die in thy seruice.

sp.speaker: Zo.
sp.p: Then here my quarrell endes, thus cease all strife.

sp.speaker: Zuc.
sp.l: Vntil they loose, men know not whats a wife,
We sleight and dully view the lampe of heauen,
Because we daylie seet, which but bereaued,
And held one little weeke from darkened eyes,
With greedy wonder, we should all admire,
Opinion of command, puts out loues fire.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p:
An Act against mummers, false seemers, that abuse ladies with counterfeit faces, courting only by signes; & seeming
wise onely by silence.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: The penalty.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: To be vrged to speake, & then if inward ability answer not outward seeming, to be committed instantly to the shippe of fooles, during great Cupids pleasure. My Lord Granuffo to the barre, speake, speake, is not this law iust?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Iust sure, for in good truth, or in good sooth, when wise men speake, they still must open their mouth.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: The brazen head haz spoken.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thou art arrested.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: And iudg'd away.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Thus silence, and graue lookes with hums and hawes,
Makes many worshipp'd, when if tried the'are dawes:
Thats the morality or lenuoy of it lenuoy of it, on.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: An act against priuie conspiracies, by which if any with ambitious wisedome, shall hope and striue to outstrippe loue to crosse his wordes, and make frustrate his sweete pleasures, if such a presumptuous wisedome fall to nothing, & die in laughter, the wizard so transgressing is ipso facto adiudged to offend in most deepe treason, to forfeite all his witt at the will of the Lord, and be instantly committed to the shippe of fooles for euer.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I marrie sir, O might Edipus riddle me out such a fellow, of all creatures breathing I doe hate those thinges that strugle to seeme wise, and yet are indeed very fooles, I remember when I was a young man in my fathers dayes, there were fower gallant spirites for resolution, as proper for body, as witty in discourse as any were in Europe, nay Europe had not such, I was one of them; wee fowre did all loue one lady, a modest chaste virgin shee was, wee all inioyde her, I well remember, and so inioyde her, that despight the strictest guard was set vpon her, wee had her at our pleasure, I speake it for her honour and my credite: where shall you finde such witty fellowes now a daies: Alas how easie it is in these weaker times to crosse loue trickes, ha ha ha alas, alas, I smile to think I must confesse with som glory to mine own wisedom, to thinke how I found out and crossed, and curbd, and ierkt, and firkte, and in the end made desperate Tiberios hope, Alas good sillie youth, that dares to cope with age, and such a beard: I speake it without glory.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: But what yet might your well known wisdome thinke
If such a one, as being most seuere,
A most protested opposite to the match
Of two young louers, who hauing bard them speech,
All interuewes, all messages, all meanes,
To plot their wished ends, euen he himselfe,
Was by their cunning made the goe betweene.
The onely messenger, the token carrier,
Tould them the times when they might fitly meete,
Nay, shew'd the way to one anothers bedde.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: May one haue the sight of such a fellow for nothing;
Doth their breath such an egregious Asse,
Is there such a foolish animal in rerum natura?
sp.p: How is it possible such a simplicitie can exist? let vs not lose our laughing at him for gods sake, let follies scepter light vpon him, and to the shippe of fooles with him instantly.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Of all these follies I arest your grace.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Mee? ha, mee? me verlet? me foole? ha, toot'h Iayle with him: what varlet call me Asse, me?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: What graue Vrbins Duke, dares Follies scepter touch his prudent shoulders, is he a Coxcombe, no, My Lord is wise, for wee all know that Vrbines Duke has eyes.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: God a mercy Fawne, hold varlet, hold thee good Fawne rayling reprobate?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Indeed I must confesse, your grace did tell,
And first did intimate your daughters loue,
To otherwise most cold Tiberio,
After conuaide her priuate fauour to him,
A curious skarfe, wherein her needle wrought,
Her priuate loue to him.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: What I do this? ha.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: And last by her perswasion shewde the youth,
The very way and best elected time,
To come vnto her chamber.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Thus did I sir?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: Thus did you sir, but I must confesse,
You ment not to doe this, but were ranckly gulde,
Made a plaine naturall. This sure sir you did.
And in assurance Prince Tiberio,
Renowmed, witted, Dulcimel appeare,
The acts of constant honor cannot feare. Herc. exit

div.stage: Tiberio and Dulcimel aboue are discouered, hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: Royally wise, and wisely royall father.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Thats sententious now, a figure calde in art Ironia.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: I humbly thanke your worthy piety, that through your only means I haue obtained so fit, louing & desired a husband.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Death, a discretion, if I should proue a foole now am not I an Asse, thinke you, ha? I will haue them both bound together, and sent to the Duke of Ferrara presently.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I am sure good Father wee are both bound together as fast as the Priest can make vs already, I thanke you for it kind father, I thanke you onely for't.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And as for sending them to the Duke of Ferrara, See my good Lord, Ferraraes oreioid prince, meetes then in fullest wish.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: By the Lord I am ashamde of my selfe, that's the plain troth, but I know now wherefore this Parliament was: what a slumber haue I been in?

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.p: Neuer grieue or wonder, all things sweetely fitte.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: There is no folly to protested wit.

sp.speaker: Herc.
sp.l: What still in wondring, ignorance doth rest,
In priuate conference, your deare lou'd brest,
Shall fully take. But now we change our face.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
Epilogus.
div.l: And thus in bolde, yet modest phrase we end,
He whose Thalia with swiftest hand hath pend,
This lighter subiect, and hath boldly torne,
Fresh bayes from Daphnes arme, doth onely scorne,
Malitious censures of some enuious few,
Who thinke they loose if others haue their due.
But let such Addars hisse, know all the sting,
All the vaine some of all those snakes that ringes
Mineruas glassefull shield can neuer taint,
Poyson or pierce, firme art disdaines to faint,
But yet of you that with impartiall faces,
With no prepared malice, but with graces,
Of sober knowledge, haue suruaide the frame,
Of his sleight scene, if you shall iudge his flame,
Distemperately, weake, as faulty much,
In stile, in plot, in spirit, loe if such
He daines in selfe accusing phrase to craue,
For prayse but pardon which he hopes to haue.
Since he protests he euer hath aspirde,
To be beloude, rather then admirde.
